title: AstraZeneca Defends Dosing Error in Covid-19 Vaccine Trial
summary: The company says its vaccine will meet regulatory approval thresholds despite snafu. A top executive at AstraZeneca PLC pushed back on Wednesday against criticism that the company failed to disclose enough data from a clinical trial of its Covid-19 vaccine earlier this week, and acknowledged skepticism about the vaccine's 90% effectiveness in a group of patients who were accidentally given a lower dose than intended.

title: Biden, Harris to Get Full Intelligence Briefings Starting Monday
summary: President-elect will start receiving president's daily brief as his team focuses on handling coronavirus pandemic. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden is expected to receive the president's daily intelligence brief starting Monday and is putting a particular emphasis on preparing to deal with the coronavirus pandemic, his transition team said.

title: James D. Wolfensohn, Ex-World Bank Chief, Dies at Age 86
summary: Australian-born investment banker helped rescue Chrysler and played the cello with Yo-Yo Ma. James D. Wolfensohn, an Australian-born investment banker who helped arrange a bailout of Chrysler Corp. in 1980 and was president of the World Bank for a decade starting in 1995, died early Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Army Corps Rejects Huge Alaskan Mine Project
summary: Move likely ends the possibility of a massive gold and copper operation in pristine wilderness. WASHINGTON-The Army Corps of Engineers rejected environmental permits for the massive Pebble Mine in Alaska, a likely death blow for plans to excavate hundreds of billions of dollars worth of gold and copper in a pristine wilderness.

title: CIA Officer Is Killed in Fighting in Somalia
summary: Death comes as Trump considers moving U.S. troops out of Somalia; no details from CIA on how or when officer died. WASHINGTON-A CIA officer was killed recently in combat in Somalia, according to current and former U.S. officials, his death coming as the Trump administration debates a plan to move hundreds of troops out of the country and reposition them in neighboring countries.

title: Hindu Nationalists' Crazy Crackdown on 'Love Jihad'
summary: Converts will need special permission to marry someone of a different religious background.. The pandemic is raging in India, economic growth is cratering, and Chinese troops are squatting on land India also claims-and the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party has odd priorities. It is determined to fight "Love Jihad," embracing a conspiracy theory that views Muslim men marrying Hindu women as an act of religious warfare.

title: Blessings in a Hard Year
summary: Among the unexpected gifts of 2020 is a newfound appreciation for people who keep America running.. It's been a fairly gruesome year-pandemic, lockdowns, economic woe, death and illness. We've done a column in past years asking friends and acquaintances what they're thankful for. This year we emailed a dozen people whom we respect and who know a lot, asking what they'd seen, experienced or realized this annus horribilis that left them moved or grateful. It could be personal or galactic in scope, concrete or abstract, but not political, and it had to be particular to this year.

title: Justice for Michael Flynn
summary: Trump's pardon for his onetime national security adviser rights a grievous wrong.. Chief Justice John Marshall once described the presidential pardon as "an act of grace." In the case of Mike Flynn, Donald Trump's pardon was something more. It was a requirement of justice.

title: A Progressive Assault on Selective High Schools
summary: Instead of fixing public education, the left tries to end testing at schools it deems inequitable.. Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring has fired the latest salvo in America's assault on meritocracy: a 61-page opinion holding that the suburban Loudoun County school system discriminated against black and Hispanic youngsters because its selective-admission high school, the Academies of Loudon, hadn't admitted enough of them. Never mind that-as Mr. Herring acknowledged-the school's test-based admissions process is open to all and fairly managed. Because its results have a "disparate impact," the school system must scrap it.

title: Covid Lockdown at the North Pole
summary: I met Santa once in a Wisconsin hotel. Now kids won't be able to find him at Macy's.. I can see him now, sitting by himself in the cramped but clean breakfast buffet area of a roadside hotel near the Fox River in eastern Wisconsin. Baggy red trousers with suspenders, full white beard, big belly, he would sometimes read the morning paper, sometimes glance at the television set bolted to the wall above the miniboxes of cereal.

title: GM Drives in Political Reverse
summary: Mary Barra drops support for a Trump suit against California.. CEOs are offering alms to win favor with their future federal regulators. This week's aim-to-please prize goes to CEO Mary Barra, who pulled the plug on GM's support for the Trump Administration in its legal challenge to California's electric car mandate.

title: A Pardon for General Flynn
summary: Finally an end to a disgraceful case of politicized prosecution.. President Trump's decision Wednesday to pardon former national security adviser Michael Flynn is an overdue act of justice that ends four years of political harassment, unjustified prosecution and judicial abuse. If it sounds like we feel strongly about this one, you're right.

title: 'Swashbuckler': Swordplay on Film Hits the Hundred-Year Mark
summary: The genre of romantic swashbuckling movies began with Douglas Fairbanks in 1920, but the term was once meant as an insult to violent braggarts. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: Facebook's Latest Error Shakes Advertisers' Confidence
summary: Company quietly told advertisers earlier this month that its 'conversion lift' tool, used to measure outcomes, overestimated some campaign results. Facebook Inc. is offering millions of dollars in credits to some advertisers after discovering a glitch in a tool that tells advertisers how effective their ads may be in driving results, such as getting consumers to download an app or purchase a product.

title: U.S. Unemployment Claims Rose to 778,000 Last Week
summary: Worker filings for jobless benefits are down sharply from a peak of nearly seven million in late March. Jobless claims rose for the second straight week, to 778,000, a sign the nationwide surge in virus cases was starting to weigh on the labor-market recovery.

title: Ahead of Black Friday, Retailers Brace for an Exceptional Holiday Season
summary: While sales are expected to rise, companies remain worried about restrictions meant to slow coronavirus infections. Retailers are bracing for an unprecedented holiday shopping season, starting with the annual Black Friday ritual, set against the backdrop of a still-raging pandemic.

title: U.S. Consumer Spending Grows for Sixth Straight Month
summary: Consumer spending rose 0.5% in October while household income fell sharply. The U.S. economy is recovering at a sturdy but slowing pace heading into the holidays.

title: Career Advice from Recent Grads and Current Students
summary: Students and young professionals share what they wish they knew about career development in their early college years. As we near the end of the year, students are considering where to apply for summer internships, or how to start plotting their first career moves after graduation in the spring. Given that this has been an academic year like no other, making plans for the future can be complicated. We asked a few WSJ Noted Advisers-our community made up primarily of aspiring journalists and young professionals, many of whom are recent grads or upper-class students, to reflect on what they learned or wish they had learned at college about developing a career. Advice from a career counselor can be useful, but it can also be helpful to hear...

title: Maradona's Death Prompts Outpouring of Grief in Argentina, World
summary: Soccer star was revered in his native land. Argentina declared three days of mourning as soccer fans across the nation poured into the streets to remember their fallen hero, the star striker Diego Maradona, after his death from a heart attack.

title: U.S. Blacklists Militia, Leader for Alleged Human Rights Abuse in Libya
summary: The sanctions come as the U.S. uses sanctions as a tool to target corruption and alleged human rights abusers-a trend likely to continue under Biden. The U.S. imposed sanctions on a militia and its leader, alleging the group was responsible for torturing and murdering civilians in Libya, the U.S. Treasury Department said.

title: Fed Signals New Guidance Coming on Asset-Purchase Program
summary: Ways that purchases could be changed to provide more stimulus to the economy, if needed, were discussed. Federal Reserve officials this month discussed plans to provide more information about how long they will keep purchasing Treasury and mortgage-backed securities by linking the time frame for the stimulus program to economic conditions.

title: TikTok Granted Extension on Divestiture Order
summary: The decision is another delay of the Trump administration's effort to turn the social-media app into an American company. WASHINGTON-Federal officials have granted TikTok and its Chinese parent ByteDance Ltd. a weeklong extension of a deadline for completing a divestiture deal, in another delay of the Trump administration's effort to turn the social-media app into an American company.

title: Stocks Pause After Dow's 30000 Milestone
summary: Blue chips decline following mixed economic readings, but Nasdaq marches to a fresh record. The Dow Jones Industrial retreated Wednesday, sliding back below 30000 after mixed economic data and the continued rise in Covid-19 cases.

title: NRA Acknowledges Improper Executive Benefits in New Tax Filing
summary: Gun-rights organization says CEO Wayne LaPierre has repaid $300,000 related to travel expenses. The National Rifle Association disclosed that current and former top executives received at least $1.4 million in improper or excessive benefits from the organization in violation of nonprofit rules, the first time the group has publicly admitted the lapses.

title: Justice Department Clears Intuit to Buy Credit Karma
summary: Credit Karma agreed to sell its tax-preparation business to Square to win antitrust approval. The Justice Department cleared Credit Karma Inc.'s pending $7.1 billion sale to TurboTax maker Intuit Inc. after the two companies agreed to divest Credit Karma's burgeoning tax-preparation business to satisfy antitrust concerns.

title: New York City Traffic Picks Up, but It Still Isn't What It Once Was
summary: Overall volume is lower, particularly in Manhattan's central business district; trucking and delivery companies are as busy as ever. The empty roads of early pandemic-era New York City have filled back up, and traffic has returned across the metropolitan region. But the gridlocked "carpocalypse" that people feared for this fall has failed to materialize and not all road trips today are as bad as they once were.

title: 'Empires of New York' Review: Big Apple, Bigger Characters
summary: A docuseries looks at the outsize and era-defining personalities of Ivan Boesky, Donald Trump, John Gotti, Leona Helmsley and Rudolph Giuliani in 1980s New York.. It comes as no small relief when "Empires of New York" dispatches the fevered imagery of its opening comments on New York City of the 1970s, and goes on to better things. We proceed, thus, from "a city on its knees in a country that was losing its mind" to one largely revived. This recovery had occurred, according to the filmmakers, thanks to the election of Ronald Reagan, who inspired enterprise and brought a new sense of life to the economy. So it's in the New York of the 1980s-prosperous, pulsating with drive and deal making of one kind or another-that the five renowned figures at the center of this six-part docuseries are shown making their marks on history. They are, to put it mildly, a varied lot: Ivan Boesky (stockbroker), Donald Trump (real-estate mogul), John Gotti (mobster), Leona Helmsley (hotel magnate), and Rudolph Giuliani, who left a significant position in Washington in 1983 to become U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: 'Zappa' Review: A Rock Star Savant
summary: A compelling documentary delivers a comprehensive portrait of provocative musical polymath Frank Zappa..

title: 'The Flight Attendant' Review: Taking Off From Reality
summary: A flight attendant struggles to return to the real world after waking up in a hotel room in Thailand and discovering a grisly scene.. It's not hard to see potential in "The Flight Attendant" (begins Thursday, HBO Max), which opens with Cassie (Kaley Cuoco), the stewardess of the title, waking up in a hotel room in Bangkok to discover a blood-drenched male corpse on the other bed. Terrified, she calls a close friend in New York to gasp out hysterical questions about the famous Amanda Knox case, and about the perils of facing a murder trial in a foreign country-Thailand, no less-whose justice system and standards of evidence bear small resemblance to the sort Americans are accustomed to. She has reason for her panic, especially since she was moved to clean up the blood and otherwise blindly push things around in what would certainly appear to police as evidence-tampering.

title: 'My Psychedelic Love Story' Review: Tales of the High Life
summary: Errol Morris focuses his latest documentary on Joanna Harcourt-Smith, hippie socialite extraordinaire and girlfriend of LSD-advocate Timothy Leary..

title: 'Smart People' Review: Prisoners of Their Politics
summary: Lydia R. Diamond's play, given a webcast reading by American Players Theatre, is a sharp satire of the progressive intelligentsia.. Lydia R. Diamond's "Smart People," a hard-edged satire of life among the academic multiculturati, was first performed off Broadway in 2016 in a production directed by Kenny Leon. I praised the play at the time as "intelligent and provocative enough to put you in mind of Tom Stoppard," and I wasn't even slightly surprised to see it taken up in short order by regional theaters. A four-character play with minimal scenic requirements, it also lends itself to small-scale bare-bones production, which makes it ideally suited to webcasting. Accordingly, Wisconsin's American Players Theatre, America's finest classical theater festival, has now put "Smart People" online as part of the company's "Out of the Woods" series of Zoom-based play readings.

title: Trump Campaign Tries to Throw Out Votes in Wisconsin Recount
summary: Election officials have largely rejected claims in latest GOP push to overturn Biden's victory in several states. MILWAUKEE-The Trump campaign and its supporters are attempting to invalidate tens of thousands of Wisconsin mail-in ballots that they say were cast illegally, their latest push to reverse a battleground state's election results favoring President-elect Joe Biden.

title: New York City Crafting Plan to Reopen Schools
summary: Mayor Bill de Blasio says he will release a plan next week outlining how in-person instruction can resume. New York City will release a plan next week showing the requirements public schools will need to meet to reopen, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Wednesday.

title: A Musical Cure for Covid-Related Stress and Sadness
summary: New research shows that playing or listening to music is the most effective way to cope with the lockdown blues.. Psychologist Susan Pinker explores new discoveries in the science of human nature. Read previous columns here.

title: Salesforce Is in Talks to Acquire Slack Technologies
summary: A deal would likely value Slack at more than $17 billion and mark Salesforce's largest acquisition ever. Salesforce.com Inc. is in advanced talks to buy Slack Technologies Inc., according to people familiar with the matter, a deal that would unite a giant in business software with a buzzy newcomer on a mission to replace office email.

title: Walmart, Grocers Can Avoid New Mexico Shutdowns With Covid-19 Testing
summary: State officials offer plan for essential businesses to avoid temporary closures from infected workers. New Mexico officials are offering grocery stores, retailers and other essential businesses a way to avoid shutdowns when workers become infected with Covid-19: regularly test all employees.

title: What to Watch on Thanksgiving
summary: Catch up on HBO's 'The Undoing' ahead of its finale, HBO Max premieres 'The Flight Attendant' and other series and movies to binge over the holiday weekend. Thanksgiving is a time for bingeing. And since we're told that the healthiest way we can celebrate the holiday this year is to sit alone on the couch with a bottle of bourbon, it's the perfect time to catch up on some shows and movies-for the first time and otherwise.

title: Covid-19 Deaths Top 100,000 in U.S. Long-Term Care Facilities
summary: The disease is particularly risky for elderly people with underlying health conditions, and nursing homes house them in close confines. The Covid-19 death toll linked to U.S. nursing homes and other long-term care facilities has surpassed 100,000, according to a Wall Street Journal tally of data from around the U.S.

title: Netflix's 'Queen's Gambit' Sparks a Chess Boom-Here's How to Get Started
summary: A drama about a fictional prodigy has newcomers signing up to play online and in real life. "The Queen's Gambit," Netflix 's fictional drama about a female chess prodigy, has pulled off an unlikely gambit of its own: It's prompted one of the biggest surges in the popularity of chess among Americans since the days of Bobby Fischer's dominance in the 1970s.

title: Biden Cabinet Picks Face Scrutiny Over Ties to WestExec Firm
summary: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee's Republicans are examining the firm's work as the panel prepares to consider Mr. Biden's national-security choices. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden's choices to lead his administration on foreign policy and intelligence both hail from a Washington advisory firm that touts its high-level connections, creating a potential stumbling block for both as they seek Senate confirmation.

title: Go Ahead, Buy a Patio Heater. Propane Is Cheap.
summary: Fortunately for those heating outdoor spaces during the Covid-19 pandemic, the U.S. has an ample propane supply. The coronavirus pandemic has made propane a hot commodity among Americans heating outdoor spaces and hunkering down in Covid cabins. Fortunately for them, the country is flooded with the fuel, and prices have rarely been lower heading into winter.

title: Delta, Pilots Strike Deal to Save Jobs
summary: Pilots accept lower pay to prevent over 1,700 furloughs as pandemic roils airline industry. Delta Air Lines Inc. pilots agreed to accept reduced pay in exchange for job security until 2022, as the industry continues to grapple with reduced travel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: For Homeowners During Covid, It's What's On the Outside That Counts
summary: Large, landscaped outdoor spaces have become a top priority during coronavirus. Covid-19 and long stretches at home have turned owners' attention to creating expansive, landscaped outdoor spaces. Keith Williams, co-owner of Nievera Williams, a landscape architecture firm in Palm Beach, Fla., says his business has been very busy. "Clients are focusing more on their gardens and how they use their exterior spaces, and just want a better and more functional experience altogether," he says.

title: U.S. Puts Tariffs on Chinese Twist-Ties
summary: Commerce Department rules that China manipulated its currency to boost its sales of plastic ties. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration has imposed a small but groundbreaking set of tariffs, penalizing Chinese twist-ties on grounds that Beijing undervalued its currency to gain market share for the products.

title: Purdue Pharma Pleads Guilty to Felonies Over OxyContin Sales
summary: Formal plea follows the approval by a bankruptcy-court judge of an $8 billion settlement with the U.S. government. Purdue Pharma LP pleaded guilty to three federal felonies related to the marketing and distribution of its powerful opioid painkiller OxyContin, ending the bankrupt company's exposure to U.S. government action but leaving other liabilities to state and local governments looming.

title: A Savory Pie Might Be the Best Move This Thanksgiving
summary: Wrapped up in comforting carbs, these main-course pastries make any occasion cozier. You don't have to wait for dessert.. IN MANY WAYS, this holiday season will be different from other holiday seasons. We won't be cooking the same feasts we would have in years past, because we won't be gathering in groups as we have in years past. But we still need that feeling of festivity, familiarity and togetherness that the holidays and the foods that go with them provide. So what can take the place of the turkeys and hams that feed multitudes, of tables groaning with sides and a battery of baked goods? What one dish can accomplish what all those others do in aggregate? My answer: the savory pie.

title: Covid-19 Aid and Stimulus: What's Expiring Soon and What's in the Works
summary: Congress faces pressure to act as extended unemployment benefits and eviction moratorium wind down- and coronavirus cases surge. Since approving a raft of coronavirus relief legislation in the spring, Congress has been unable to come together on a new aid package. The Trump administration took a number of executive actions to provide further aid during the impasse. With the end of the year approaching, several of the legislative and executive measures are set to expire, putting pressure on Congress to agree to further relief as cases of the virus set records and businesses face new restrictions.

title: Covid Won't Steal Christmas
summary: This holiday shopping season will be different, but there will be shopping. This holiday season will be different from any other, including what people choose to spend money on.

title: Thanksgiving Dessert Recipe: So Much Simpler Than Pumpkin Pie
summary: Iconoclastic though it may be to oust the Thanksgiving classic in favor of a French recipe, one taste of this silky, souffléed pumpkin dessert and you'll never go back. IN AMERICA, pumpkin pie is nearly as entrenched a ritual as apple pie-despite the fact that so many people don't actually like it. Most of my family falls squarely in that camp, so I've experimented with alternatives over the years. Finally I stumbled upon an old Burgundian cookbook with a recipe for a "flamusse" of pumpkin. This looked promising.

title: Don't Judge This English Home by Its Traditional Facade
summary: A glass wall at the back of the Surrey property helped expand the estate while giving it a modern, contemporary look. Behind a very traditional facade, Rob and Cath Shrimplin's house is hiding a contemporary surprise.

title: Fiduciary Regulation for Retirement Plans Is Now in Limbo
summary: Delays on proposed fiduciary rule have made it vulnerable to being scrapped under Biden administration. In June, the U.S. Department of Labor proposed a regulation to change the rules governing advice in retirement accounts to align with another Trump administration standard. But delays in completing the proposal, likely due in part to financial-industry opposition, have left it vulnerable to being scrapped after President-elect Joe Biden takes office.

title: Turkeys Truly Worth Celebrating
summary: On a Georgia farm, a group of veterans is acquiring unexpected skills while raising heritage-breed turkeys beloved by cooks. Plus, how to find and roast a heritage bird from a farm near you for the holiday table.. THE TUESDAY before Thanksgiving will be among the busiest days of the year at Comfort Farms in Milledgeville, Ga. Local families will visit to collect their holiday turkeys, a total of roughly 40 Bourbon Reds, raised on site. For some, claiming the bird is a simple pick-up-and-go process. But others will actually partake in harvesting it themselves, from slaughter to shrink-wrapping.

title: Deere Expects More Machinery Sales as Crop Prices Rise
summary: Higher food sales to pandemic-bound consumers and China are boosting demand for tractors and combines. Deere & Co. raised expectations for profits next year, anticipating that higher crop prices will lead to improving demand from U.S. farmers for its tractors and harvesting combines.

title: Saudi Women's Rights Activist Championed in the West to Face Terrorism Charges
summary: Loujain al-Hathloul became a focus of Western attention after her arrest in 2017. RIYADH-Saudi Arabia transferred the case of women's rights activist Loujain al-Hathloul to a terrorism court, raising fears among supporters that she could remain in prison longer despite international pressure to release her.

title: There Are More Female CEOs Than Ever, and Many of Them Are in Retail
summary: Lauren Hobart's appointment to helm of Dick's Sporting Goods brings number of women running Fortune 500 companies to a record. In a year especially hard on many working women, the corporate world can hail one major milestone: A record 41 female CEOs are slated to be soon running Fortune 500 companies.

title: Thanksgiving Baking Strategy: One Recipe, Two Desserts
summary: Be smart when it comes to the sweets and get more bang for your bake. Each of these recipes produces a stunning tart or cake for the holiday table plus a bonus treat for the next day.. OVERWHELMED by coordinating the usual Thanksgiving spread this year? You are not alone. As a professional pastry chef, I'm used to fancy equipment, plenty of space and skilled staff to help me execute my dishes. So when I lost my service-industry job earlier this year due to the pandemic, I fretted over how I would make my favorite desserts out of my tiny Brooklyn kitchen. (First step: Buy whisk.)

title: Former J. Crew CEO Mickey Drexler Sells Idaho Home for $11 Million
summary: The Thierry W. Despont-designed ski property includes two adjacent lots. Former J.Crew chief Mickey Drexler has sold his Ketchum, Idaho, home and two adjacent lots for $11 million, according to people familiar with the transaction.

title: Cottage Meets Contemporary in Surrey
summary: A glass wall at the back of the property brings in lots of light while giving the home a modern edge.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: China's Xi Congratulates Biden Weeks After Other Leaders
summary: Message, coming after Trump said administration will cooperate with transition, underlines Beijing's desire to stabilize the relationship. HONG KONG-President Xi Jinping congratulated U.S. President-elect Joe Biden on his election victory, marking the Chinese leader's first formal outreach to the incoming administration weeks after many other world leaders sent well wishes.

title: Indian State Tries to Stop Marriages That Hindu Nationalists Say Are Part of 'Love Jihad' Conspiracy
summary: Critics say the new law opens the door to harassment of interfaith couples and Muslims. NEW DELHI-India's most populous state approved legislation requiring interfaith couples to give two-months notice before getting married, in the latest example of a policy backed by the Hindu right becoming law.

title: Recipes for a Smaller Holiday Meal With Big Flavor
summary: Even scaled-down celebrations call for exceptional spice and color. Paprika-rubbed roast chicken, pomegranate-flecked wheat berry pudding and more will satisfy a small gathering with outsize expectations.. I ARRIVED in the U.S. as a 17-year-old university student. And while I usually traveled home to Jerusalem for Christmas, I learned to navigate other holidays-from Eid to Easter-without my family. Now, my husband, two daughters and I make it to Jerusalem from our home in Philadelphia at least once a year, but we celebrate the majority of holidays with my husband's family here. As much as I enjoy those feasts, I am still keenly aware of the absence of my own parents, brother and extended family.

title: Scotland to Provide Tampons and Pads Free of Charge
summary: Some women and girls have found it difficult to access sanitary products during Covid-19 lockdowns. Scotland has launched one of the biggest efforts yet to make tampons and sanitary pads free for anyone who needs them as lockdowns around the world have made it harder for women and girls to obtain period products.

title: Former Priest Offered Guidance on Dilemmas of Dying
summary: Albert Jonsen, who has died at age 89, helped shape the field of bioethics. In the late 1960s, when medical ethics began emerging as a distinct field of study, Albert Jonsen was ready to contribute.

title: GE Appliances Turns Up the Speed on Supply-Chain Upgrade
summary: Coronavirus-driven disruptions in demand and production added urgency to an effort aimed at building visibility and flexibility. GE Appliances was in the midst of a digital supply-chain upgrade when the coronavirus pandemic hit, disrupting global supply lines while consumer demand soared for the company's refrigerators and washing machines.

title: Can RadioShack Be the Right Type of Retro?
summary: The doomed retailer has a new online presence but appears off to a mixed start. The Shack is back! Well, sort of.

title: Penguin Random House Parent to Buy Simon & Schuster From ViacomCBS
summary: A $2 billion-plus deal would consolidate largest and third-largest book publishers in the U.S.. ViacomCBS Inc. is selling book publisher Simon & Schuster to German media giant Bertelsmann SE for almost $2.18 billion, ViacomCBS said Wednesday, in a deal that would create a publishing behemoth accounting for about a third of all books sold in the U.S.

title: Diego Maradona, Soccer's Flawed Genius, Dies at 60
summary: Resume Subscription. Diego Maradona, the outlandish and dazzling Argentine soccer star considered among the greatest of all time on the field and the most outrageous off of it, died on Wednesday following a cardiac arrest. He was 60.

title: Soaring Covid-19 Hospitalizations Again Put Traveling Nurses in Demand
summary: Hospitals pay as much as double to staff up as nurses move from one hot spot to another. As the number of people hospitalized due to the coronavirus rises across the U.S., hospitals are turning to a tactic they used in earlier surges: hiring more traveling nurses.

title: Can North Korea Control Its Nuclear Weapons?
summary: Now that Pyongyang's missiles can hit the U.S. mainland, avoiding calamity means grappling with the nuclear command systems of Kim Jong Un's monolithic regime. As Americans mark Thanksgiving this year amid the pandemic, North Korea will be recalling a special anniversary of its own. On Nov. 28, 2017, dictator Kim Jong Un oversaw the launch of the largest missile ever flight-tested by the world's last Stalinist country. Called the Hwasong (or "Mars") 15, the missile showed that North Korea is capable of striking any part of the continental U.S.-from Los Angeles to New York-with a thermonuclear weapon.

title: Thanksgiving and the American Character
summary: A former colleague's exploration of the great holiday.. Covid will not stop Americans from embracing their annual Thanksgiving traditions involving charity, family, faith, food and football. And they might want to consider adding a new tradition this year as they gather around the dinner table-sharing a few passages from our former colleague Melanie Kirkpatrick's delightful 2016 book, "Thanksgiving: The Holiday at the Heart of the American Experience."

title: Europe Won't Push Biden for Swift U.S. Return to Iranian Nuclear Deal
summary: There is growing concern about Iran's nuclear research, but European diplomats say they don't want to rush new U.S. president to re-enter pact. European powers are looking to the incoming Biden administration to swiftly reduce nuclear tensions with Tehran but won't press Washington to re-enter the 2015 nuclear accord with Iran quickly, according to senior diplomats.

title: Global Trade Stages Rapid Recovery
summary: Led by China, the rebound in exports and imports of goods has been much quicker than in the aftermath of the global financial crisis. Global trade flows bounced back strongly in the summer, marking the largest rise in two decades as air and sea transport channels reopened while demand for consumer goods surged.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Building Vaccine Supply Chains; Delivery's Uphill Climb; Farming Looks Up
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Gap, Deere, HP, Dell: What to Watch When the Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stocks wavered a day after the Dow breached 30000 for the first time.. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Wednesday:

title: He Used to Guard the Door. Now He Takes Names and Temperatures, Too.
summary: As the pandemic rages on, a Madison Avenue security worker's job has expanded: keep merchandise safe, and protect shoppers and staff from the virus. Francisco Teran has been a security guard at a luxury watch store in Manhattan's Upper East Side for almost two years. These days it feels like a totally new job.

title: From Miley Cyrus to Kylie Minogue, the Best Songs You Should Be Listening to Right Now
summary: Not ready for 24/7 Christmas songs yet? Here's WSJ.'s monthly roundup of new pop releases: Everything that's grabbing our attention, making us think or getting us dancing.. South Korean boy band BTS, WSJ. Magazine's 2020 Music Innovators, released their highly anticipated new album BE this month, featuring their new single "Life Goes On." The song, which combines a hip-hop beat with the loop of an acoustic guitar, is about moving forward in the face of hardship. "I first study the topic and think about what story I need to tell and what kind of content it should encompass," band member J-Hope told WSJ. about his songwriting process. "Sometimes the type of stories I'm dealing with are light, but sometimes they aren't, so it's important that I'm knowledgeable about what I'm working on."

title: Covid Scrambles College Basketball Season Before It Starts
summary: 'DM or call me,' one coach tweeted in search of a new opponent after the original foe canceled. Dozens of games have been canceled or postponed.. It was Monday when Jeff Walz, coach of the No. 5 Louisville women's basketball team, heard the Cardinals' season opener Wednesday against Middle Tennessee State was off because of Covid-19 infections and contact tracing among the Blue Raiders. So Walz did what any responsible coach would do in 2020: He took to Twitter .

title: Split-Ticket Voters Helped Biden, Republicans in Nebraska, Maine
summary: Dividing votes between parties has been declining, but 2020 election saw enough people vote that way to matter in places. On evening walks with his wife in the suburbs of Omaha, Neb., Jay Jackson, a registered Republican and an Air Force veteran, made the decision to vote for Democrat Joe Biden for president and support Republicans for all other offices.

title: New Covid-19 Vaccines Stir Hope for the World's Poor
summary: Promising trial results inspire optimism in the developing world, which could yet become a reservoir for the virus for years to come.

title: China Drugmakers Face Pressure to Prove Their Covid-19 Vaccines Work
summary: The companies haven't released results of late-stage trials while data from Western drugmakers show three candidates to be highly promising. TAIPEI-Pressure is mounting on Chinese drugmakers to show clinical evidence that their leading Covid-19 vaccines work, after early data on three Western-developed shots showed promising effectiveness against the disease.

title: Dow's Milestone Heralds Broader Stock Rally
summary: Gains in cyclical stocks will test whether a new group of companies can lead major indexes higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average's ascent to 30000 Tuesday signals more companies are beginning to participate in the new bull market, offering hope to investors who have long waited for the rally to widen.

title: Exxon Documents Reveal More Pessimistic Outlook for Oil Prices
summary: The oil giant has lowered its expectations for prices for much of the next decade, internal documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal show. Exxon Mobil Corp. has lowered its outlook on oil prices for much of the next decade, according to internal company documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Under Shadow of Corruption, Peru's Congress Fuels Crisis
summary: Majority of Peruvian lawmakers are under investigation for bribery and other crimes, stirring anger and destabilizing the country's leadership. LIMA, Peru-Peruvian politician Humberto Acuña was convicted of bribery committed while he was governor of a northern Peruvian state from 2011 to 2018, and still faces several other charges, including abuse of authority and criminal conspiracy.

title: The Stock Market Keeps Rising, but Millennials Aren't Reaping the Benefits
summary: Resume Subscription. Many millennials, having suffered through two nasty bear markets in the first years of their working lives, are missing out on some of the gains from the rally that brought the Dow Jones Industrial Average to 30,000.

title: Most Americans Worry Government Is Tracking Them With Location Data
summary: Quarter of poll respondents say they will change behavior to avoid surveillance. A new survey found widespread concern among Americans about government tracking of their whereabouts through their digital devices, with an overwhelming majority saying that a warrant should be required to obtain such data.

title: Big Oil's Lessons for the New Green Supermajors
summary: Once humble utility companies, Enel and Iberdrola have emerged as global clean-energy giants. The decline of oil-and-gas supermajors over the past two years has been matched by the rise of previously obscure utility companies. In Europe, Enel and Iberdrola have emerged as green-energy giants, in part by taking leaves out of the big-oil playbook.

title: In Singapore, Bargains for Luxury Homes Are Few and Far Between
summary: Resume Subscription. Priyesh Shah looked at more than a dozen high-end apartments in Singapore as he searched recently for a permanent home for his young family. The New Jersey native has worked in Singapore for eight years and, like many others, hoped the coronavirus-triggered economic downturn would be a good buying opportunity.

title: Regulatory Pressure Mounts on Coal Miner that Rattled China's Bond Market
summary: Investigation into state-owned Yongcheng Coal is escalated to country's securities regulator. An investigation into a troubled Chinese state-owned coal miner was escalated to the country's securities regulator, as authorities pile pressure on the company whose recent default rattled the bond market.

title: Behind Dow 30000: A Self-Perpetuating Upward Spiral
summary: Low interest rates and a buy-the-dip mantra have put stocks in an ascending pattern, defying the pandemic and economic woes. The U.S. stock boom has its roots in tactics that fund managers, small savers and Robinhood traders alike have applied over the past decade:

title: Europe Doubles Down on Data Protection to Ward Off Silicon Valley, Chinese Influence
summary: New EU proposal aims to offer protections for corporate and public-service data as GDPR covers individuals. The European Union wants to take control of its own data, part of a broader effort to wrest digital influence from large companies in the U.S. and China.

title: Lessons From Europe's Covid Surge: Control Is Fragile and Losing It Is Easy
summary: Resume Subscription. Europe seemed to have Covid-19 under control this summer, enough so that authorities let residents travel more freely among the region's countries again. Then tourists flew home from vacations with the pathogen, seeding fresh outbreaks.

title: HBO Max Hopes 'Flight Attendant' Will Land Viewers
summary: Streaming service's new boss sees shows targeting women and younger viewers as way to stand out in cluttered video market. Casey Bloys was hunting for a hit that could help the new HBO Max streaming service stand out in an increasingly fragmented video market-and help differentiate it from HBO, the premium cable home to "Succession" and "Game of Thrones."

title: Climate Researchers Enlist Big Cloud Providers for Big Data Challenges
summary: Amazon, Google and Microsoft increasingly are providing the computing muscle scientists need to glean insights from vast stores of climate data. The cloud's ability to chew through vast amounts of data using machine-learning algorithms is drawing in more researchers from the data-intensive world of climate science.

title: Coca-Cola CFO Helps Company Make Cuts, Operational Changes
summary: The beverage giant is reducing the number of its brands and shrinking head count. Coca-Cola Co. 's finance chief John Murphy is helping the company shrink its product portfolio along with its head count as part of a restructuring effort responding to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Dow 30000 and the Problem With Long-Term Capitalism
summary: Unprecedented economic support and the rapid development of vaccines have helped investors look far beyond the horizon, but that carries risks of its own. The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit 30000 for the first time on Tuesday, after a rally of more than 60% from its March lows.

title: JD Health IPO Adds to Hale and Hearty Hong Kong Market
summary: The deal will help lift proceeds from Hong Kong IPOs and secondary listings to a 10-year high. Hong Kong is having a standout year for stock listings, despite political turmoil and the derailment of the world's largest initial public offering.

title: EU Official Raises Vetting Concerns Over BlackRock Contract
summary: European Commission is urged to update guidance on hiring contractors with potential conflicts of interest. A European Union watchdog said Wednesday the bloc's executive branch failed to properly consider potential conflicts of interest when it chose BlackRock Inc. to advise the EU on future banking regulations.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
